bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, December 18, 1897

div1.p: Reed appreciates the care given his father Lemuel S. Reed by his sister. He discusses an African-American nurse for his father, a visit by his nephew Olin Blincoe, and other family news. [Courtesy of the Library of Virginia]

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, December 18, 1897
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Dec. 18, '97
My darling Sister:
div1.p:
You must
pardon my delay in an-
swering yours of Dec. 4,
I have tried forty times
to get the opportunity of
answering, but have slipped
up every time. You must
apologize for me to dear
Pa for my almost utter
neglect in writing to him;
I think of him many times
every day, and knowing that
he is in good hands, I
try not to worry about
him. Am so glad that he
is getting along fairly
well - If he gets that
Darkey Nurse, I should
like to hear the conversa-
tions between them! They
could well be worth
recording, & some of them
would brighten Harper's
Drawer, I am sure!
By all means, get the
Darkey Nurse!
Your boy, Olin, has
been to see us -- came
Sunday afternoon on
his wheel & spent an
hour - He looked
well & seemed con-
tented with his posi-
tion. Will take dinner
with us tomorrow,
when we hope to
become better ac-
quainted with him.
I have told him not
to expect any calls from
me, as I am so busy
till April 18th -

Give Pa, Ma &
Annie much love-
Try to brace Pa up all
you can - Discuss prize
fighting with him - He
seemed to enjoy that more
than anything else when
I was there! unless it
was my “bossing him”!
I think that he appreciated
the latter immensely!
I used to make him go to
sleep whether he wanted to or
not, & didn't give him any
powder either! With lots
of love,
div1.closer: your affectionate bro, Walter R. 23783 e
